paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted information on the KCNH2 variant c.1930 G>T p.V644F, including penetrance data and individual records.

patients.demographics: 76-year-old male (proband), son, grandson, granddaughter (ages not specified)

individual_records.phenotype_details: frequent syncopal attacks, QT prolongation >600 ms
individual_records.evidence_sentence: A 76-year-old man had syncopal attacks with remarkable QT interval prolongation (QT>600 ms) since he was 62 years old.

individual_records.phenotype_details: diagnosed with LQT on ECG, repetitive syncope due to TdP
individual_records.evidence_sentence: a mutation also present in his son, grandson, and granddaughter, all were diagnosed with LQT on ECG.

individual_records.phenotype_details: diagnosed with LQT on ECG, repetitive syncope due to TdP
individual_records.evidence_sentence: a mutation also present in his son, grandson, and granddaughter, all were diagnosed with LQT on ECG.

individual_records.phenotype_details: diagnosed with LQT on ECG, repetitive syncope due to TdP
individual_records.evidence_sentence: a mutation also present in his son, grandson, and granddaughter, all were diagnosed with LQT on ECG.

functional_data.summary: The KCNH2-V644F mutation is located in segment 6 (S6) of the KCNH2 (HERG) channel, indicating a higher risk of cardiac events.

variants.segregation_data: Yes, the variant segregates with disease in the family.
variants.additional_notes: The KCNH2-V644F mutation is associated with a significant family history of LQT2.
key_quotes: This KCNH2-V644F mutation is located in segment 6 (S6) of the KCNH2 (HERG) channel, indicating a higher risk of cardiac events.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data regarding the KCNH2 variant was successfully extracted.
